wikipedia_page.main: John Randolph Sutton (24 July 1888 – 28 February 1969) was an English singer and comic entertainer in music hall and variety shows.

response: * George Alex Stevens (1875–1954), composer of "On Mother Kelly's Doorstep" sung by Randolph Sutton.

He is a lover of avant-garde music and a patron of, among others, the French composer Jean-Michel Damase and the Melba Foundation in Australia. Humphries is a patron and active supporter of the Tait Memorial Trust in London, a charity to support young Australian performing artists in the UK. When Humphries was on the BBC's Desert Island Discs radio programme in 2009, he made the following choices: "" from Strauss' Der Rosenkavalier; Gershwin's "Things are Looking Up" sung by Fred Astaire; "Love Song" composed by Josef Suk; "On Mother Kelly's Doorstep" sung by Randolph Sutton; "" from Schubert's Winterreise song cycle; the 2nd movement of Poulenc's Flute Sonata; Mischa Spoliansky's ""; and "They are not long the weeping and the laughter" from Delius' Songs of Sunset.Programme: Desert Island Discs, BBC Radio 4, 29 May 2009

response: One of his best-known songs was "On Mother Kelly's Doorstep".  The song was first published in 1925, when it was recorded by Tom Barratt, "On Mother Kelly's Doorstep" by Tom Barratt, Winner Records, Discogs. Retrieved 3 January 2021 and was made popular by Randolph Sutton although Sutton did not record it for many years.Roy Hudd and Philip Hindin, Roy Hudd's Cavalcade of Variety Acts, Robson Books, 1998, , p.177  Danny La Rue's 1968 version of the song reached number 33 in the UK singles chart; La Rue later adopted the song as his theme tune.

Kate Carney featured his song "Mother I Love You" for more than 40 years. In later years he wrote "Chump Chop and Chips" for Gracie Fields.  Randolph Sutton sang his "When the Harvest Moon is Shining" on early TV, and comedian Reg Dixon revived his "I'm Shy Mary Ellen, I'm Shy", first published in 1910.

link_mentions.page: List of acts that have appeared on the Royal Variety Performance

response: He also put together a very successful theatre show of retired or semi-retired music hall stars in the nostalgic 1948 revue Thanks for the Memory, "a fast-moving production featuring many younger supporting artists".  The featured music hall stars included such performers as Gertie Gitana, G. H. Elliott, Nellie Wallace, Randolph Sutton, Ella Shields, and Talbot O'Farrell. Marilyn Shalks, "1948 sees the Palace Theatre say ‘Thanks for the memory!’", Manchester Theatre History, 28 October 2020. Retrieved 2 December 2020   There were lengthy quarrels between some of the performers over who should have top billing and the best dressing room, as well as their fees, but despite the problems the show proved to be a huge success.Richard Anthony Baker, Old Time Variety: an illustrated history, Pen & Sword, 2011, , pp.251-254   Highlights from the show featured in the 1948 Royal Variety Performance,Raymond Mander and Joe Mitchenson, British Music Hall: A story in pictures, Studio Vista, 1965, p.194 and it ran at Blackpool in 1949 and 1950.  The closing performance of the show, in December 1950, was recorded by BBC Radio and later made available on CD.

The song was published in 1931 by the firm of Campbell Connelly.  It was immediately recorded by several leading British acts, including Jack Leon, Bobbie Comber, Randolph Sutton, Billy Cotton, Jay Wilbur, Jack Hylton, and Leslie Sarony."Jolly Good Company", SecondhandSongs. Retrieved 5 January 2021 Marie-Thérèse O'Loughlin, "Jolly Good Company", GoldenBridgeInmate. Retrieved 5 January 2021  In 1932 it was adopted as the theme song of The Canada Dry Ginger Ale Program on American radio, starring Jack Benny. "Mary Livingstone Meets Jack Benny", Tralfaz, 1 May 2016. Retrieved 5 January 2021
